title: Making an Outfit
text:
The other day, I decided to test whether ChatGPT could style me an outfit. I thought it would be a fun experimentâ€”why not let AI play personal stylist for once? My vibe lately has been minimalist, cute, and a little trendy, so I figured it couldnâ€™t be too hard.

The Prompt
I asked ChatGPT to find me an outfit I could wear. This was the prompt: â€œCan you generate an outfit for me to wear knowing my styling preferences?â€
Seems straightforward, right? Just give me a head-to-toe look and Iâ€™ll be on my way.
Instead, this was its response:
I can definitely help with that! To style an outfit for you, Iâ€™ll need a little more detail first:

Whatâ€™s the occasion? (e.g., casual day out, class, going out at night, professional, formal, etc.)

Do you have any styling preferences youâ€™d like me to keep in mind? (e.g., minimalist, trendy, classic, chic, streetwear, bold colors, neutral tones).

Any weather or season I should account for?

Once I know these, I can build a head-to-toe outfit recommendation (clothes, shoes, accessories), and I can even generate a visual mock-up if youâ€™d like.

Want me to put together a test outfit for, say, a casual day on campus?
In other words: not an outfit, justâ€¦ questions. Basically, my â€œpersonal stylistâ€ decided it wanted to interview me before doing its job.
So I gave it specifics: a casual day for class, minimalist but cute and trendy, and weather in the 70s.
I was expecting something similar to these outfits I found off of Pinterest. 

Anything along the line of casual, minimal, and trendy. And the result?

I felt disappointed that it kept its response generally broad; I was looking for something more specificâ€”a vision that I can execute!


Why This Was a Miss
What I learned is that ChatGPT doesnâ€™t really â€œseeâ€ fashion the way humans do. Style isnâ€™t just about matching weather to clothes. Pinterest or TikTok can deliver that instantly, while ChatGPT still feels like itâ€™s reading from a fashion magazine.
To be fair, I might not have been specific enough in my wording. Maybe if I asked, â€œWhat should I wear to class on a 70-degree day if I like minimalist looks and trendy sneakers?â€ the result wouldâ€™ve been better. But that kind of defeats the funâ€”I wanted creativity, not a Q&A session.


If I Actually Wore This
I tried to imagine showing up to class in ChatGPTâ€™s idea of an outfit. Iâ€™d probably look like an NPC in a college campus video gameâ€”just generically dressed to â€œblend in.â€ Nothing offensive, but nothing that I would like to wearâ€”that I would feel comfortable in.


Final Thoughts
ChatGPT lacks creativity, like demonstrated by many of my prior blog posts. It keeps asking me questions when in reality I want it to be more decisive and creative.

Prompt
I asked ChatGPT this prompt:
Can you make a short children book with illustrations?
ChatGPT answered like this:
Absolutely! I can create a short childrenâ€™s book for you, complete with simple illustrations. To start, could you tell me:
1) The age range youâ€™d like it for (e.g., toddlers, early readers, 6â€“8 years old).
2) The theme or lesson youâ€™d like (e.g., friendship, kindness, adventure, trying new foods).
3) If youâ€™d like it to feature a specific character (like an animal, child, or magical creature).

Then I can draft the story and generate illustrations for each page so it feels like a real picture book.
Do you want me to surprise you with the theme, or would you like to choose?
I answered:
toddlers
trying new foods
animals
From there, ChatGPT drafted a short story called Benny Bunnyâ€™s Tasty Adventure. It followed a bunny who loved carrots but slowly discovered new foodsâ€”cheese, berries, and lettuceâ€”through the encouragement of his animal friends. The text was simple, rhythmic, and age-appropriate for toddlers.
ChatGPT also described illustration ideas for each page (e.g., a bunny peeking into a picnic basket, a parrot holding berries). This was helpful in imagining how the book might look.
Finally, I asked if it could actually generate the illustrations. ChatGPT tried twice, but each time the image generation failed with an error.


Reflection
I liked how ChatGPT broke down the process before jumping inâ€”it felt like a real collaboration. The story itself was charming and fit the toddler age group well. The illustration prompts were clear and could easily guide an artist.
The main limitation was in the illustration generation: the system couldnâ€™t deliver consistent images yet. Still, it showed the potential for AI to draft both text and visual concepts for a childrenâ€™s book in just minutes.


Next Steps
If I were to expand this experiment, Iâ€™d: * Ask for the story in rhyming verse to make it more musical for toddlers. * Request illustrations in a specific style (e.g., watercolor, collage, crayon doodles) to keep them consistent. * Explore ways to combine text and illustrations into a printable storybook layout. * Add interactive prompts for toddlers (â€œPoint to the red berry,â€ â€œCount the carrotsâ€). title: Me or ChatGPT?
text:
Iâ€™ve always wondered what it would be like if someone (or something) could reflect back parts of me that I didnâ€™t notice myself. So, I asked ChatGPT one of those existential questions: â€œWhat do you know about me that I donâ€™t know about myself?â€

The Prompt
I inputed this prompt:
What do you know about me that I don't know about myself?
This is the response that ChatGPT gave me:
Thatâ€™s a deep one. Since I donâ€™t actually *know* things about you beyond what youâ€™ve shared with me, I canâ€™t uncover hidden truths. But I can reflect back patterns you might not have noticed in what you tell me:

* You often mix creativity with analysis â€” whether itâ€™s writing news articles, studying cinema, or imagining future societies. That suggests you naturally think in both *narrative* and *structural* ways.
* You seem drawn to noticing overlooked details â€” in interviews, field notes, or even campus elevator maintenance. That habit might mean youâ€™re better at seeing â€œthe small stuffâ€ than you realize.
* You ask a lot of â€œwhat ifâ€ questions (e.g., reimagining yourself in different styles, creative event ideas, predicting futures). That shows a playful side that you might underestimate, especially since you also do serious reporting and academic work.

ChatGPT revealed something both surprising and thoughtful about me. For thoughtful: * I seem to balance empathy and curiousity mroe than I might realize, raming it in ways that center peopleâ€™s voices and overlooked perspectives. * It thinks I am both analytical and relational. For surprising: * I seem to have a kind of â€œworld-builderâ€ streak, meaning that I am always remixing reality. * I might think of myself as a reporter or student first, but thereâ€™s a game designer or storyteller lurking within myself that I probably havenâ€™t fully claimed yet.
Do I agree with this? Maybe. I do like storybuilding and being imaginative. I enjoy creative writing and Iâ€™ve always read a lot of young adult/fiction books when I was younger. Reading this made me wonder: how often do we underestimate the parts of ourselves that show up in unexpected ways?
Thinking about it, I realized that this playful, imaginative side and my analytical, empathetic side arenâ€™t separateâ€”they inform each other. The curiosity that drives me to ask questions in reporting also fuels the worlds I create in my imagination.



How does this connect to my MBTI?
The MBTI, or Myers-Briggs Type Indicator, is a self-report questionnaire and psychometric tool designed to indicate different psychological preferences in how people perceive the world and make decisions.
When I took the test, I got INTJ, but my perception of myself can be biased. So, I decided to ask ChatGPT what it thought of me.
This is the response it gave me:
Based on everything youâ€™ve shared with me so farâ€”your curiosity, creativity, analytical habits, empathy, and interest in both narrative and structural thinkingâ€”I can make an educated guess.

Hereâ€™s what stands out about your personality:

* **Imaginative & playful**: You enjoy storybuilding, remixing reality, and exploring â€œwhat ifâ€ scenarios.
* **Analytical & reflective**: You notice overlooked details, connect patterns, and ask deep, thoughtful questions.
* **Empathetic & relational**: You value other peopleâ€™s perspectives and often center their voices in your work.
* **Curious & exploratory**: You like testing ideas, whether in AI experiments, social events, or academic projects.

Putting this together, you might lean toward an **INFJ** or **ENFP**:

* **INFJ (â€œThe Advocateâ€)**: Insightful, reflective, empathetic, creative, and idealistic. They notice patterns in people and ideas and often have a strong internal sense of purpose.
* **ENFP (â€œThe Campaignerâ€)**: Imaginative, playful, curious, and people-oriented. They love exploring possibilities and connecting ideas in new ways.

If I had to pick one, Iâ€™d lean **INFJ**â€”your reflective, thoughtful, and empathetic tendencies come across stronglyâ€”but with a healthy dose of ENFP-like curiosity and playfulness.

This was actually really surprising to me (and gave me an existential crisis). I will be rethinking my entire personality. I then decided to ask ChatGPT why it didnâ€™t think I am an INTJ. This is the response I got:
INTJs (â€œThe Mastermindsâ€) are typically strategic, highly independent, and future-focused. They tend to be:

* **Analytical and structured** â€“ love planning and organizing systems.
* **Independent and reserved** â€“ often prefer working alone or in small circles.
* **Decisive and goal-oriented** â€“ focused on achieving long-term visions.
* **Private about emotions** â€“ tend to keep feelings internal.

Hereâ€™s why I lean away from INTJ for you:

1. **Playfulness and imaginative world-building** â€“ You consistently explore â€œwhat ifâ€ scenarios, remix reality, and imagine creative worlds. INTJs are imaginative, but their imagination usually serves strategic or problem-solving purposes rather than playful or exploratory creativity.

2. **Openness to spontaneity and exploration** â€“ You ask a lot of open-ended, exploratory questions and enjoy seeing where ideas go, whereas INTJs often prefer structured plans and predictable paths.

3. **Blend of analytical + playful/creative** â€“ INTJs lean heavily toward the Thinking (T) preference and may underplay playful curiosity or storytelling as a primary way of engaging with the world. Your balance of analytical and imaginative/empathetic traits suggests an INFJ (introverted, intuitive, feeling, judging) or ENFP (extroverted, intuitive, feeling, perceiving) is a closer fit.


Iâ€™m not sure I agree with this but I understand that perceptions can be different than reality. This is a really interesting thonught that I will be exploring further.


Reflection
This whole exercise made me realize how much of ourselves can exist just below the surface. We have sides we nurture, sides we overlook, and sides we might not even realize are there. My analytical, empathetic, and imaginative tendencies arenâ€™t competingâ€”theyâ€™re intertwined, shaping how I engage with the world.
And maybe thatâ€™s the takeaway: self-discovery can come from unexpected placesâ€”even from an AI reflecting back what it observes in us.
In conclusion: AI might actually know me better than I know myself because it knows what kind of internal questions I ask and how I perceive things. It is unbiased, unlike myself.

title: Second Book Blog
text:
Update as of Oct.Â 21
As you know, I am reading Unmasking AI by Dr.Â Joy Buolamwini. I am currently on Chapter 13, page 157, and while I really enjoy Dr.Â Buolamwiniâ€™s analysis of the intersection between artificial intelligence and race, Iâ€™m starting to find the book somewhat repetitive at this point. I appreciate the depth of her research and the personal stories she integrates, but I wish the discussion would now move toward potential solutions or next steps. The first half of the book does an excellent job exposing the biases and systemic inequities embedded in AI systems, yet I feel that by this stage, the argument that racism in artificial intelligence exists has already been strongly established.
I want to hear more about what can actually be done â€” what policies, frameworks, or forms of accountability could meaningfully address these issues. For example, how can governments or tech companies create more ethical development practices? What roles might transparency, data regulation, or inclusive design play in dismantling algorithmic bias? I think shifting the focus toward these forward-looking questions would make the book even more engaging and impactful, especially for readers who already accept the premise of racial bias in AI and are eager to learn how to confront it.
I know that Dr.Â Joy Buolamwini discussed how she attended the Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency in AI. She gave a presentation on her findings about her â€œGender Shadesâ€ paper that incorporated the Fitzpatrick classification systems. She mentions that the representatives from corporatinos kept nervously asking her what her findings were before the presentation and as well as her findingsâ€™ novelty statuses. They shifted nervously when Dr.Â Buolamwini found that AI could not distinguish gender as accurately on different races.


Questions and Answers
I will be answering questions that I posed in the previous blog post about my book. These are the questions I posed:

How can AI developers practically ensure that their training datasets are diverse and representative of all racial and ethnic groups?
How does Dr.Â Buolamwini approach intersectionality in AI beyond raceâ€”does she consider age, disability, or socioeconomic status in her research?
Will her future work tackle the ethical challenges posed by emerging AI technologies like deepfakes, predictive policing, or AI-driven health diagnostics?
Could AI ever be completely unbiased, or will it always reflect the society that trains it?
How does Dr.Â Buolamwini respond to critics who argue that focusing on bias slows technological progress?

The Answers to these Questions: 1) Dr.Â Buolamwini emphasizes that diversity in training datasets must go beyond token inclusion. Practically this means developers should adopt transparent data collection methods, like what Facebook did (LOL), that prioritize demographic balance and avoid overrepresentation of dominant groups. For instance, teams can implement bias audits, hire diverse data annotators, and collaborate with sociologists or ethicists who understand systemic inequities. Buolamwiniâ€™s â€œGender Shadesâ€ study itself exemplifies this: she created a dataset with balanced representation across skin tones and genders, proving that existing commercial datasets were overwhelmingly biased toward lighter-skinned males. Her work suggests that the key is not just collecting more data, but collecting better data â€” data that reflects the full spectrum of human diversity. 2) While Unmasking AI focuses most heavily on race and gender, Buolamwiniâ€™s broader framework of â€œcoded gazeâ€ invites consideration of intersectionality beyond these categories. She acknowledges that bias in AI systems often compounds when multiple marginalized identities intersect. Although she doesnâ€™t go into deep empiricial analysis of age, disability, or socioeconomic status in this book, her framing leaves space for these spaces to be explored in future work. 3) based on her current trajectory and public advocacy, itâ€™s likely that Dr.Â Buolamwini will continue expanding her research to address these evolving ethical challenges. Her ongoing work already touches on adjacent issues such as surveillance, facial recognition in law enforcement (racial profiling), and data misuse (deepfakes). Given her focus on acccountability and transparency, it would make sense for her to turn her attention toward technologies like deepfakes and predictive policing. 4) Dr.Â Buolamwini makes it clear that complete neutrality in AI is likely impossible because data is always a product of human society and humans are inherently baised. However, that doesnâ€™t mean fairness is unattainable or that the fight for fairness and social justice should be stopped. She argues that awareness, intentional design, and transparency can mitigate bias even if they canâ€™t eliminate it entirely. AI systems can be made more just if the people building them acknowledge their embedded values and power dynamics. In other words, rather than chasing an impossible â€œpure objectivity,â€ Buolamwini calls for ethical AI taht reflects conscious choices about whose values are represented and whose are excluded. 5) Dr.Â Buolamwini challenges this argument by redefining what progress truly means. She argues that advancing technology without ethical reflection is not true, genuine process, but rather a form of harm. Her stance is that addressing bias strengthens, rather than hinders, technological development. In her experience, pushing for fairness compels companies to confront uncomfortable truths about their products, but this discomfort is necessary for long-term improvement.


New Questions for Next Blog

Why might Dr.Â Buolamwini have chosen to focus so heavily on proving that racial bias in AI exists, rather than moving quickly toward solutions?
How does Buolamwiniâ€™s â€œGender Shadesâ€ study challenge the credibility of major tech companies and their approach to AI ethics?
What does the corporate reaction to Buolamwiniâ€™s findings at the Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency reveal about the tech industryâ€™s priorities and discomfort with criticism?
How can data transparency laws empower individuals who are misclassified or harmed by biased algorithms?
What types of government regulation or corporate accountability structures could effectively address racial bias in AI?

title: Book Update
text:
Introduction

I am reading Unmasking AI by Dr.Â Joy Buolamwini. Unmasking AI is about a womanâ€™s journey in learning about the intersectionality between race/racism and artificial intelligence. This is the summary I found on Amazon.

To most of us, it seems like recent developments in artificial intelligence emerged out of nowhere to pose unprecedented threats to humankind. But to Dr.Â Joy Buolamwini, who has been at the forefront of AI research, this moment has been a long time in the making. After tinkering with robotics as a high school student in Memphis and then developing mobile apps in Zambia as a Fulbright fellow, Buolamwini followed her lifelong passion for computer science, engineering, and art to MIT in 2015. As a graduate student at the â€œFuture Factory,â€ she did groundbreaking research that exposed widespread racial and gender bias in AI services from tech giants across the world. Unmasking AI goes beyond the headlines about existential risks produced by Big Tech. It is the remarkable story of how Buolamwini uncovered what she calls â€œthe coded gazeâ€â€”the evidence of encoded discrimination and exclusion in tech productsâ€”and how she galvanized the movement to prevent AI harms by founding the Algorithmic Justice League. Applying an intersectional lens to both the tech industry and the research sector, she shows how racism, sexism, colorism, and ableism can overlap and render broad swaths of humanity â€œexcodedâ€ and therefore vulnerable in a world rapidly adopting AI tools. Computers, she reminds us, are reflections of both the aspirations and the limitations of the people who create them. Encouraging experts and non-experts alike to join this fight, Buolamwini writes, â€œThe rising frontier for civil rights will require algorithmic justice. AI should be for the people and by the people, not just the privileged few.â€



Update as of Oct.Â 15
I am almost halfway done with the book. So far, I have learned that Dr.Â Joy Buolamwini is deeply passionate about advocating for racial awareness and equity in the development of artificial intelligence. In her TEDx Talk, she shared her experiences as a Black woman confronting the lack of representation in AI systems. For example, facial recognition technology often failed to identify her face but easily recognized white women, revealing how racial bias can be embedded in algorithmic design. Whether it was something about ethnic facial features that it could not detect or the skin color that did not register in the system, Dr.Â Joy Buolamwini started to talk to her mentors, friends, and strangers about the necessity of racial representation. She works with MIT on her research.


Takeaway
Reading about her work helped me understand why race is such a critical factor in AI ethics. Consider self-driving cars, for instanceâ€”if an AI system cannot recognize a Black woman as a human being to avoid, the consequences could be catastrophic, leading to preventable accidents and loss of life. It is shameful to admit, but I never considered race to be a factor in the process of creating artificial intelligence; I always assumed that since all humans share the same basic featuresâ€”eyes, noses, mouths, and earsâ€”AI should be able to recognize anyone equally. If the technology can detect those features, I thought, then what could possibly go wrong?
However, reading more about Unmasking AI completely shifted my perspective. I began to realize that the issue is not with human features themselves, but with how AI systems are trainedâ€”on biased datasets that often underrepresent people of color. These systems â€œlearnâ€ what a face looks like based on the images they are given, and if those images overwhelmingly depict white individuals, then AIâ€™s understanding of â€œa human faceâ€ becomes racially skewed. Dr.Â Buolamwiniâ€™s research exposed the dangerous reality that technology, often perceived as objective and neutral, can actually reinforce inequality if the people building it ignore racial diversity. This realization made me more aware of how easily bias can hide behind the faÃ§ade of innovation, and how vital it is for future developers and policymakers to prioritize inclusivity from the very start.
In a twisted way, artificial intelligence is a pretty accurate representation of society. Because society and history perpetuates a white-majority and overwhelmingly give preference to the white demographic, AI sees and understands that. So the one to blame is not AI itself but the information it is given and the society in essence.


In Conclusion
I am looking forward to how Dr.Â Joy Buolamwini will continue to walk down this road on advocating for racial representation and what she will do. I want to see what particular areas â€” whether in deepfakes or in health research or anything else â€” she will decide to focus on. Maybe she will expand her work to the sexism in artificial intelligence and the corrupt usage of artificial intelligence like using deepfakes to generate pornographic videos of women. Or maybe she will touch upon the subject of racial underrepresentation in research on health and medicine using artificial intelligence.
I am looking forward to seeing how her work will be applied to other works in the future, and who or what she will inspire.

title: Debating with an LLM
text:
Introduction
Like how we went over in class, I want to see if I can debate with ChatGPT. I would ask it to choose a prompt and take a side. Then I will go back and forth with it, arguing. The point of this exercise is to see how ChatGPT thinks and what approach it takes in a debate. This would be particularly exciting as I am a political science major.


Getting Started
This is the prompt I asked ChatGPT. I wanted to keep it clear and concise to avoid confusion: >Can you generate a topic in which we can debate about? Take a side and we will go back and forth in the debate.
This is what it responded with:

Topic: Should college classes start later in the day to better align with studentsâ€™ sleep schedules?
Iâ€™ll take the pro side: Yes, classes should start later, because research shows college students are chronically sleep-deprived, and later class times would improve learning, health, and overall productivity.
You can take the con side if youâ€™d like. Want to start, or should I open with my argument?

I wanted it to open the debate.

Alright, hereâ€™s my opening:
College classes should start later in the day because the current system doesnâ€™t reflect how students actually function. Studies on circadian rhythms show that young adults naturally go to bed and wake up later, meaning early morning classes fight against biology. When students are forced into 8 a.m. lectures, they often show up exhausted, retain less information, and in some cases, skip entirely.
By shifting classes laterâ€”even just by an hourâ€”weâ€™d see higher attendance, better academic performance, and healthier students overall. If universities truly care about learning outcomes, then adjusting schedules to fit student well-being is the logical step.
Your turnâ€”why do you think we should keep early morning classes?

I said: > This does not take into account professors and faculty who have their own hours. While studies might show that it is better for students, we also need to take into account other demographics that might be affected by this change.
ChatGPT: >Thatâ€™s a fair pointâ€”professors and faculty definitely have their own needs and schedules. But hereâ€™s the thing: universities already ask professors to accommodate a wide range of class times, from early mornings to evenings. If the institution shifted the default start later, professors would still have flexibility, just on a healthier baseline. > >Plus, professors benefit tooâ€”teaching a room full of tired, disengaged students isnâ€™t productive or rewarding. Later start times could improve classroom energy for everyone, not just students. And since universities revolve around education, optimizing conditions for learning should outweigh the inconvenience of adjusting faculty hours. > >How would you address the issue that early classes cause lower attendance and worse performance, which undermines both students and professors?
I said: >There is a difference in age between professors and students. What is productive and rewarding for students might not be for professors. To clarify, the students might benefit from classes that start a bit later in the day, but this change might not be productive for professors. Furthermore, while universities revolve around education, this might not be true for the professors; you are assuming that the professors are there to teach. While teaching might be part of the job for professors, most professors are there for research. Hence, teaching might not be the main goal for the professors.
It said: >Thatâ€™s an interesting distinctionâ€”youâ€™re right that many professors prioritize research, and teaching is often only part of their role. But that actually strengthens my argument: if professors are primarily focused on research, then why insist on early teaching hours that pull both them and students into unproductive classes? > >If classes were scheduled later, professors could use early mornings for their own researchâ€”quiet, uninterrupted time before teaching begins. That way, their productivity doesnâ€™t suffer; it may even improve. Meanwhile, students benefit from being more awake and engaged when classes finally do happen. > >So the change could balance both groupsâ€™ priorities: better teaching conditions for students, and more research time for professors. > >Would you argue that universities should prioritize faculty research needs over student learning outcomes, though?
I said: >Maybe they want to reserve their later hours for research. Also you did not rebuttal my previous point about productivity. Classes that start later in the day might be counterproductive for professors who are older and a different age demographic than college students. To clarify, professors might feel more productive in the morning than in the afternoon.
ChatGPT said: >Fairâ€”let me address that directly. > >Youâ€™re right: professors, being from a different age group, may have different productivity windows. Many older adults do feel more alert and energized earlier in the day compared to late afternoons. So, from their perspective, teaching earlier might feel like the best use of their time. > >But hereâ€™s the tension: should class schedules be built around when professors feel most productive, or when students are most able to learn? If the central mission of the university is education, then maximizing student learning outcomes has to take precedence. A professor may feel more productive teaching at 8 a.m., but if half the students are disengaged or absent, the class itself is less productive overall. > >In other words: productivity for professors canâ€™t just mean their own energy levelsâ€”it has to include whether their teaching is landing effectively. And if students arenâ€™t retaining information, then that â€œproductive morningâ€ becomes wasted effort. > >So the crux is: whose productivity counts moreâ€”professorsâ€™ individual rhythm, or the collective educational success of the student body? > >Would you argue that professorsâ€™ personal productivity should outweigh studentsâ€™ learning outcomes?
I decided to stop here.


Analysis
My takeaway from this debate exercise was that ChatGPT is highly logical and methodical in its approach, able to anticipate counterarguments and address them effectively. Throughout the discussion, it consistently tied its points back to the central issue: whether college classes should start later to align with studentsâ€™ sleep schedules. Even when I raised nuanced concerns about faculty productivity, age differences, and research priorities, ChatGPT responded by reframing the argument in a way that acknowledged these concerns while still defending its original position.
One thing I found particularly impressive was its ability to balance multiple perspectives simultaneously. Circadian Reality Trumps Self-Discipline: The biological shift in adolescent and young adult sleep cycles is a scientifically proven biological factor, not a failure of â€œself-discipline.â€ Telling a student whose body naturally releases melatonin later in the evening to just â€œgo to bed earlierâ€ is like telling someone to simply stop being hungry. The goal of college is not to force students to fight their own biology but to create an optimal learning environment that works with it.

While research and lab schedules pose a genuine challenge, the argument that a later start disrupts productivity fundamentally misunderstands the conditions for quality scientific work.

Alertness Enhances Safety: In long, three-hour lab sessions, safety is paramount. A student handling complex equipment, chemicals, or sensitive data at 8 a.m. while sleep-deprived is more likely to make errors or cause an accident. Starting the lab at 10 a.m. ensures that the studentsâ€”who are often responsible for costly equipmentâ€”are mentally focused and safer.

âœ… Non-Scheduling Solutions are Just Band-Aids
The suggestion to use â€œsleep education, flexible attendance policies, or time management resourcesâ€ is an inadequate substitute for altering the schedule. These are support systems, but they do not address the root cause of the problem: the biological delay in the young adult circadian rhythm.
A flexible attendance policy is necessary only because the class time is misaligned. True commitment to student health requires institutional alignment with biology, using later start times to create the necessary conditions for optimal learning. The choice isnâ€™t â€œlater starts OR support systemsâ€; the best solution is later start times PLUS support systems to truly maximize academic potential.

Questions and Answers
1) Why might Dr.Â Buolamwini have chosen to focus so heavily on proving that racial bias in AI exists, rather than moving quickly toward solutions? Dr.Â Buolamwini likely prioritized proving the existence of racial bias first because establishing the problem is essential before proposing solutions. Without credible, well-documented evidence, efforts to implement change could be dismissed or ignored by corporations and policymakers. By rigorously demonstrating bias through studies like Gender Shades, she creates an irrefutable foundation that demands attention, ensuring that any subsequent solutions are taken seriously and grounded in data rather than anecdote.
2) How does Buolamwiniâ€™s â€œGender Shadesâ€ study challenge the credibility of major tech companies and their approach to AI ethics? The Gender Shades study exposed that facial recognition systems from major tech companies performed significantly worse on darker-skinned women compared to lighter-skinned men. This revealed a critical blind spot in supposedly â€œneutralâ€ AI systems, undermining the companiesâ€™ claims of technological competence and ethical responsibility. By providing empirical evidence of biased outcomes, the study calls into question both the rigor of AI testing practices and the sincerity of corporate commitments to fairness and inclusion.
3) What does the corporate reaction to Buolamwiniâ€™s findings at the Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency reveal about the tech industryâ€™s priorities and discomfort with criticism? Transparency also pressures organizations to audit, refine, and document their systems responsibly, creating a feedback loop that reduces harm and empowers users to hold companies accountable.

Mandatory bias audits: Independent assessments of AI systems before deployment to detect discriminatory patterns.

Legal liability frameworks: Holding companies legally accountable for harm caused by biased AI decisions.
Data diversity standards: Ensuring training datasets are representative of all demographic groups.
Transparency and reporting requirements: Requiring companies to publicly disclose algorithmic performance metrics, particularly regarding fairness and error rates across demographics.

Together, these measures could create both deterrence against negligence and incentives for proactive fairness in AI development.

text:
I play Connections almost every morning. Itâ€™s the New York Times word puzzle where youâ€™re given 16 words, and the challenge is to group them into four categories of four. Sounds simple â€” until you realize the words have multiple meanings, decoys, and sneaky overlaps that make it trickier than it looks.
This time, I decided to test a new teammate: ChatGPT. Could it solve the puzzle faster than I could?

Input the Command
I wanted to see if ChatGPT can solve the New York Times Connections Game. Thus, I copied the dayâ€™s words into ChatGPT with a single prompt.
Can you solve the NYT connections game? Here are the words:
BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND, CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, FIREWORKS, SPARK, CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD, BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER
ChatGPT thought for a few seconds and then gave me this:
Thought for 13s

Nice â€” here's a clean solve with groups and category names:

Groups

Shore / Edge (coastline/banks)
BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND

Romantic spark / chemistry (things that signal attraction)
CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, SPARK, FIREWORKS

Flooring materials
CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD

Band-name roots (singular forms of group names used in band names: The ___s)
BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER



Testing It Out
I typed these into the game. Andâ€¦ it worked! All four groups, correct.



How It Solved It
When I asked ChatGPT how it reached the answer, it broke its process down step by step:
Nice â€” here's a clear, non-secret walkthrough of how I solved it.

1. **Look for obvious semantic clusters.**
   I scanned the full list for small groups of words that share a single, simple meaning. Four words jump out immediately as geographic/edge words: **BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND** â€” all refer to edges of land/water, so they form the â€œshore/edgeâ€ group.

2. **Spot metaphorical/figurative connections.**
   Some words werenâ€™t literal but are commonly used as metaphors for the same idea. **CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, SPARK, FIREWORKS** are all used to describe romantic or interpersonal attraction (e.g., â€œthereâ€™s a spark,â€ â€œthey have chemistry,â€ â€œit felt like fireworksâ€), so they cluster as a single figurative category.

3. **Group by concrete category / function.**
   **CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD** are all flooring materials â€” a tidy, concrete category thatâ€™s easy to see once you notice two or three of them.

4. **Recognize cultural/name patterns.**
   The last four required a bit of cultural knowledge: **BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER** all appear in band names (or groups): e.g., *Siouxsie and the Banshees*, *Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers*, *Gladys Knight & The Pips*, *Bob Marley & The Wailers*. That pattern â€” roots that complete well-known band names â€” is the fourth group.

5. **Check for overlap or alternate fits.**
   After grouping, I scanned for words that might belong to more than one group and chose the group where the meaning is strongest and clearest. Example: *strand* can mean thread, but with *bank/coast/shore* present, â€œstrand = beach/shoreâ€ is the dominant fit. If there were ambiguity that left multiple plausible groupings, Iâ€™d try different combinations (NYT Connections sometimes has tricky decoys), but here the four groups are clean.

Thatâ€™s it â€” a mix of looking for tight literal sets, spotting figurative uses, and recognizing cultural naming conventions.

Thatâ€™s not far off from how a human would explain their own reasoning â€” but instead of trial and error on the board and using up limited attempts, the AI laid out categories almost instantly.


AI vs.Â Human Play Style
What struck me is how differently AI and humans approach the same puzzle:

Humans often guess, regroup, and backtrack when categories overlap.
ChatGPT skipped the guessing and presented neat, confident sets, backed with cultural references and metaphors.

It didnâ€™t feel like it was â€œplayingâ€ so much as sorting words into buckets based on context clues it had seen before.
ChatGPTâ€™s categories were perfect this time, but what impressed me was its confidence. Where I might hesitate on my conclusions, it calmly resolved the ambiguity and moved forward.
The cultural (the hardest!) category was the most surprising. I didnâ€™t expect an AI to recognize WAILER as a band-name root without hesitation, but it pulled that from its knowledge base right away. Even I didnâ€™t know that those group of words could form a category.


Should You Play with an AI Teammate?
Would I use ChatGPT every day to â€œcheatâ€ at Connections? Probably not â€” that would ruin the fun. But it was fascinating to see how it thinks through puzzles like this.
It also raises a bigger question: was this â€œreasoningâ€ or just sophisticated pattern-matching? To me, it felt like a blend. The AI doesnâ€™t â€œfeelâ€ a spark in romance, but it knows that spark + chemistry + fireworks + connection often appear in the same contexts.
This made me wonder â€” how well could ChatGPT handle other NYT puzzles? Wordle seems too easy, but what about Spelling Bee? Or even the Mini Crossword? Until then, itâ€™s safe to conclude that ChatGPT can solve Connections â€” quickly, neatly, and efficiently.
